meanings.definition: To move to a new place.
meanings.sent1: The family decided to relocate to a bigger house in the city.
meanings.sent2: They will relocate to a new apartment next month.
meanings.sent3: The cat tried to relocate to the top shelf but got stuck halfway.
meanings.sent4: The birds relocate to warmer regions during the winter months.
meanings.sent5: After the flood, the residents had to relocate to temporary shelters.

meanings.definition: To move to a different location.
meanings.sent1: The company will relocate its headquarters to a new city.
meanings.sent2: We need to relocate the picnic to a shadier spot.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel tried to relocate its acorns but kept forgetting where.
meanings.sent4: The clouds seem to relocate across the sky as the day goes on.
meanings.sent5: The nomadic tribe would relocate frequently in search of better grazing lands.

meanings.definition: To transfer to a new position or job.
meanings.sent1: She decided to relocate to a different department for a new challenge.
meanings.sent2: The manager offered to relocate him to the overseas branch.
meanings.sent3: The robot asked for an upgrade to relocate to a more advanced task.
meanings.sent4: The student had to relocate to a different school due to the family's move.
meanings.sent5: The athlete was excited to relocate to a team with better training facilities.
